commentBody: That‚Äôs more like it
I really liked 9 down.
Sharp! üòÄ
NICE PUTT.

I want to start by thanking Sam for her pointed comments and sharp wit in the Wordplay column.

This was a nice Tuesday, and a nice debut, so thank you, Jared. No major problems solving this one; my only mistake was LOTta instead of LOTSA, but that was quickly corrected when I looked at the down entry. Fun puzzle!
Faster than yesterday.  Fun.
This Harvey dude who picked up his first win on Jeopardy! this evening might be around for a while. At least, I hope so. Dominant victory by an inspiring man.

So a bit of a side issue, but -

Anybody else unhappy with the 6A "joke" clue in the mini? 
Putting the answer word in the clue - even as a joke - IS NOT FUNNY!
Fun puzzle, and a great debut. 62A: "A golfer's play on a cheeky compliment?" Thank you, I'll see myself out...

Never have had acupuncture, but have been a blood and platelet donor many times,
another way to GET THE POINT.

Things a donor would prefer not to hear:
HOPE SO
UH UH
TRIED
MOVE THE NEEDLE

But it almost always goes swimmingly.  Next time my person gets a good stick, I‚Äôll be tempted to say:
NICE PUTT!

I think my comment got picked up by the civility filter, so I'll try again. Got all mixed up with 68-A, since I had 51-D ending with a T. Took a solid three minutes to work it out, since I had SORENTa instead of SORENTO, too

I love the needlelike verticality of the theme and the fact that the clue for IDIOM is ‚ÄúA pain in the neck‚Äù.

Congratulations, Jared, on a jab well done!

Congratulations a clever debut, Mr. Cappel!

I loved the theme ‚Äì and I can relate to it.
I've gotten the STAB IN THE BACK quite a few times, as well as on my legs, feet, hands, and ears. Because of the amazing results, despite my initial skepticism, I have every reason to believe it's not a placebo effect. 

After my first ACUPUNCTURE treatment in the early 90's, I became very interested in Chinese medicine (as well as Eastern philosophy), and I find beauty in the concept of the meridians that run through the body.

Other entries that spoke to me were OSKAR Schindler, a true mensch, and Hermann Hesse, a great author (yes, I LOVEd the movie Schindler's List, though I  bawled like a baby, and the book Siddhartha, though I was still quite young and not yet attuned to spiritual quests.)

Thank you, Mr Cappel. 
Your puzzle was a very satisfying and peace-inducing sojourn away from the news.
Sam, the cutline for the drawing at the head of your column is priceless!  It made my day, so thank you!  (The crossword was fun to solve, too.)

I liked this puzzle a lot.  

There's been so much lately about proper nouns.  I thought this one was short on them, so I started to count.  Then I realized I don't really know what "proper nouns" are.

Is CANOLA a proper noun?  How about LGPA?  Or ERIE?  Is a lake allowed as a proper noun?  Or RASTA?
A particularly thorny puzzle.

Nice debut, Jared.  You managed to calm the screams of pain from the wounded Monday solvers without boring the rest of us.  

It was not a difficult puzzle, but nicely put together, with some chewy clues threaded throughout.  Thank you, and I hope we see more of your constructions before too long.

"Should we go to the acupuncturist?"
"Ooh, maybe. Let's put a pin in that."

("Point well taken.")

I just wanted to say that the suggestion yesterday that soon we will have an entry so niche that it will be the constructor's mother's social security number was outrageous.

This is a crossword puzzle after all.

Not a sudoku (sp?).

But I think it would be great if it turned out one of the niche entries was the constructor's mother's maiden name.

[But I have to admit that I thought the comment was hilarious.]
Much more fun than yesterday fewer TLAs although IDEST crossed with PDA made no sense to me at all.

Great puzzle. Just the right amount of thinking for a Tuesday. I thoroughly enjoyed it. Especially, after Sunday and Monday. Please save any comments about the previous 2 puzzles being fine, that's your opinion and this is mine - they were a pain in the neck.

Yesterday‚Äôs brouhaha over proper names got me thinking about how they can be as much of a help to some solvers as they are a hindrance to others.

When I started doing crosswords, the wordplay in the clues was intimidating. I didn‚Äôt know what to make of clues ending in ‚Äú, say‚Äù or a question mark. Could I trust the ones that seemed more straightforward? And wait, now you‚Äôre telling me the answer can be more than one word?

Within this sea of uncertainty, proper names were a godsend. Same goes for pop culture titles. They were unambiguous, they didn‚Äôt have multiple possible synonyms, and they often became the crosses that brought clarity to tougher clues. Did I know them all? Of course not. But the ones I did were immensely helpful.

So when a veteran solver gets stumped by a person, title or term that seems too niche for the NYT crossword, I would ask them to consider that that Thing they‚Äôve never heard of may also be a novice‚Äôs way in. Even (or especially?) on a Monday!
Really enjoyed this puzzle, and was delighted to see the creator is from Toronto, a city we love (go Blue Jays!)
The crosses of LPGA / PROAM, LOTSA / ASTIN (initially had lotta, couldn't work out what was wrong) and OSKAR / ARTIE / IOWAN were painful for me personally..

This was so much easier than yesterday's puzzle - my solve time yesterday was nearing Wednesday territory, and today it was Monday-ish.

I've had a rough morning - our old Jorge the Lab is in poor health, and even though my wife and I are providing him with the best veterinary care available, there are some really bad days and nights, which take their toll on all of us, canine and human alike. Today started as one of those days...

I approached today's grid still shaken by the dog's episode, as well as yesterday's unpleasant crossword experience, so I did not try to suss out LPGA and PROAM - I simply looked those up when the crosses I had on my first pass did not reveal all the letters there. Golf does not exist in my world, and while I have heard of LPGA, PROAM looks like a letter salad to me (but names and words like Szczebrzeszyn, rzerzƒÖczka, ≈õr√≥dziemnomorski or szczerbaty I perceive as completely normal. Go figure).

Other than that it was a nice, quite relaxing puzzle, with a good enough theme.

Gather ye ROSEBUDS.
Any puzzle with Idris ELBA in it is okay by me. How is that after all this time I'm only realizing now that his name is also Napoleon's island?
Thanks, Jared

Nice, only one reveal. like yesterday - the golf initials.

Had to smile at 'reeks', reminded of the old name of my home town of Edinburgh (Ed-in-buh-ruh please) which was Auld Reekie, mainly because of the smoke from coal fires. Reeks was more associated with being smoky than stinky. London used to be called The Smoke.

A good luck saying is "Lang may your lum reek" - long may your chimney smoke; it was also good luck to bring a lump of coal on your first visit to a house on New Year's Day, especially if you were the First Foot - the first to cross the threshold.
Fantastic! What a great Tuesday with a theme. Thanks for the smiles :) hope you're not afraid of needles

Strand Thread: Strands #373 ‚ÄúWhat's the magic word?‚Äù üü°üîµüîµüîµ üîµüîµ Please, please, please no spoilers until after the View All Replies button. Thank you, thank you, thank you. Got a reply from the games Care team. Won't quote it. Preference was expressed that we hang our Strands comments in the Bee column comments. I've checked that out and it is certainly very lively. When I looked there were over 45 comment. Here's today's thread: https://www.nytimes.com/shared/comment/45utdg?rsrc=cshare&smid=url-share

Fantastic debut!

I do love my Idris Elba‚Ä¶

This time of year (where I live) 
tends to wear on people.

The rare sunlight melts the
once beautiful snow 
into blackened lumps along the curbs.

The first real signs of spring
are so subtle, everything just looks dreary
and feels heavy.

Wishing you all a bright Tuesday
with plenty of serotonin, vitamin D,
and a little spring in your step!
Congratulations to Jared for a really fun puzzle and I hope he gets his wish for many more of his puzzles to be shared with us.

Nice Tuesday puzzle and an enjoyable workout. The reveal was one of the last things I worked out and that was a nice 'aha' moment as the theme finally dawned on me. 

Did get stuck for just a bit in a couple of places. One example was in the area of SMH, which is not a familiar term. No big deal - managed to work it out. 

Quite a remarkable puzzle find today. I'll put that in a reply. 

...

I wrote a brief comment last night to say (read, brag just a little) that solving this fine puzzle brought my streak to 1,000, which I'm kinda proud of. As I noted, there aren't many other groups of folks in the world that might appreciate it.  I was BEMUSEd this morning to find that my post had been eaten by emus.  Anyway, thanks to Mr Cappel for pushing me over the top.

Some crunch, some fun. Loved the theme, although I kept trying to spell it ACCUPUNCTURE with 2 Cs (which obviously did not fit). Enjoyed  NICE PUTT, ROSEBUDS and STAMEN (the last of which took embarrassingly long). Thanks!

I like that the theme answers are step-by-step in proper order.  First the acupuncturist gets the needle, then places it in, then may move it.  So, they tell a little story.  Nice touch, Jared.

Those theme answers are zingy too, and are bolstered by a supporting cast of lovelies ‚Äì ROPE IN, CANAPES, SKITTLES, BEMUSE.  All these lovelies occupy the middle three rows, making that area sing.

Uncovering the reveal ACUPUNCTURE brought a huge ‚ÄúHah!‚Äù and ‚ÄúGood one!‚Äù.

That delight, as well as the fact that the puzzle-maker is an upper-level Scrabble competitor, brings the promise of a new and special voice in Crosslandia.  Not only is Jared a wonk adept at manipulating words and letters, but also an entertainer.

So, I was not only charmed by your puzzle, Jared, but also touched by hope for the future.  What a gift!  Thank you, Jared, and please, keep ‚Äòem coming!

Sign seen near recently opened rose buds?

EAT AT STAMEN.


(This post is lame enough to make a bee muse.)
Top left stumped me for a whole but I eventually got there. Nice puzzle overall

A much more Tuesday-like puzzle, not that I didn‚Äôt get a kick out of yesterday‚Äôs brute.

I got the theme revealer first, so had fun finding the NEEDLES as it were. My only real struggle was 1A/2D. Needed all the crosses to get there. I was thinking meet? Track? before hitting PRO AM. Hah, that raised a chuckle.

Blenheim PALACE is a fabulous place to visit. More humongous mansion than actual palace, the extensive gardens and woods are  incredibly beautiful and a joy to spend a day in. I once treated Mum to a birthday afternoon tea in the Indian Room. You can keep your teas at the Ritz or Savoy. THAT was a spectacular feast in one of the most ornate rooms I‚Äôve ever sat in, overlooking (if memory serves) the formal knotted garden. Even better, the staff were professional but super friendly, so we weren‚Äôt in fear of being snubbed for picking up the wrong fork! Oh the horror of upper class etiquette.
This is a great puzzle :)

Rather than a "first all the across, then all the downs" approach I just follow the crosses.  So this turned out to be a west to east solve and about half way through I wondered if there was a theme.  

That thought bubble was burst with the reveal at 27D.   Nicely done.
LPGA is much more than a pro-am coordinator.  Great to call out the LPGA, not so great to downplay what they do.

Fine debut! 
If anyone is considering ACUPUNCTURE for migraine relief, it did help my mother. 
Love the picture - even at 65, I'd love to put on those contraptions and bounce around!

Many gimmes, as befits a Tuesday....especially WELTY!  Her home and garden here in the capital city of Jackson are shrines; Millsaps College (the private liberal arts school that spawns most professionals in this state) teaches her writings.  One of the other residents here lent me a book of her short works...which I found very dated--"Old School" is the polite term in these parts.  Woof.

Other than that...
Blenheim is generally referred to as a CASTLE, methinks.

Ah, Socrates.  Have someone "think" about shoelaces instead of TEACHing them how to tie them; best of luck to ya.  (My kids were still 2 when I taught them how--using "backward chaining."  Works like a charm.)  

An ACUPUNCTURist who STABS with the NEEDLES won't have a clientele for long!

See you tomorrow!

Word pairs that have the same amount of letters, thus tripping me up when I try to enter them in a crossword:

--Pistil and STAMEN
--Mauna Loa and Mauna KEA
--Sasha and Malia Obama
--Jerry's friends Elaine, George, and Kramer
--Sierra Madre and Sierra Leone
--Mattress makers Serta and Sealy

Can anyone think of more examples?
Easy fun! Thanks!
Had my first 60 degree day yesterday after a long Wisconsin winter. Spring has sprung!! This puzzle was great.

I believe the column photo is the first patent application filed by Acme Corp. Fun puzzle. Surprising, to me, theme. There was a live-action animated movie about Wile E. Coyote suing Acme. I can't remember hearing about it previously, and it sounds like we'll never see it as it remains unreleased for tax purposes. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coyote_vs._Acme

Some thoughts about yesterday's puzzle vis-a-vis today's:

One of my comments yesterday was that while my solve time was actually faster than my Monday average, I could see how it might have been difficult for newcomers. According to xwstats.com, I finished 37.6% faster than usual for a Monday, but the puzzle was rated Hard.  However, xwstats went on to say that the breakdown of faster vs. slower than average was 49% to 51%. (Not sure how that comports with a rating of Hard.) The median solve time was only 1% slower. Also, 14% solved much faster (>20% faster), and 22% solved much slower (also >20%). 

This bears out my theory that this was a puzzle that bifurcates distinctly between veteran solvers and newbies.  The comments add anecdotal evidence to support that theory.

Today's puzzle, on the other hand, was considered Average, with a median solve time 15% faster than normal for Tuesday. Also, 79% of members solved faster (39% much faster) and 21% solved slower (7% much slower) than usual. My time, however, was 27.6% faster than my Tuesday average, and the two days' times were very much in line with the weekly progression (a ratio of approximately 15 to 16, without revealing actual times, which set a lot of people off!)

With a caveat that xwstats uses the solve times of only those who have signed up, you can still see patterns. Overall, it seems that Monday's puzzle falls in line with the usual progression, even though some had great difficulty with it.

Anyone else have this issue with XWstats? Mine says I solved today's puzzle 2:20 faster than my average. But by my calculations it's only 1:15 faster. It's a bit closer when you only look at the last 60 days, but still not quite right (2:03 faster). And it's also not accurate compared to my NYT stats. Monday's stats were closer, but still off.
Other than wasting 2 minutes reasonably thinking ‚Äúa pain in the neck, e.g.‚Äù was IDIOT, fun and painless.
Had to come here to tell some word nerds that AS OF NOW I hit 1,000 on my streak today. Most normal folks would be BEMUSEd but not amused. Cheers!

Congrats on the debut. I wondered why the thematic entries were verticals, and my guess was confirmed in the constructor's notes.

Seemed like a lot of proper nouns again today, but, like yesterday, I knew almost all of them. Even recalled OSKAR, WELTY, SORENTO, ASTIN and HESSE.

Parsing PROAM might have been my biggest challenge here.

Seemed like a solid Tuesday puzzle to me.

Congrats to my buddy Jared, an amazing player at the Toronto Scrabble Club. If he tackles crossword construction with the same determination that he has with Scrabble, he‚Äôll be hitting the ‚Äòcycle‚Äô in record time!

Fun puzzle. Probably would have done better, had I not kept falling asleep. Maybe I should finish my coffee? Not sure why I'm so sleepy...maybe the time change is catching up to me.

We're having our annual Pi Day Party this weekend (day after Pi Day, though, since it's a Saturday) and I have to get off my duff and make another pie. Anyone bringing a pie is welcome; show up without one and you are required to recite Pi to its first billion (leaving you unable to have the time to taste anyone else's pie). A few years ago, The NY Times published a special XWrd for 3.14 day and I printed it out for guests to try...hoping for another this year! (Or just publish the link to the old one...I've got a mostly new group of people this year.)

My chicken pot pie is done...now on to a dessert pie.

Favorite clue of the day: Sample sake, say: SIP. Go ahead, say it out loud. It's a great tongue twister!

My spirits dropped when I read 1A, but actually I had a lot of fun and obscure US sport trivia wasn't as prominent as I feared.
Lovely little theme, I especially enjoyed that they were Down clues looking like needles pricking into a patient when you click on 27D :)
Many thanks Jared, super puzzle!

I have a real blind spot when it comes to the phrase EATAT. It's not a phrase I ever use but I have seen it a couple handfuls of times since I've been doing the puzzles, and I totally get it, but unless I have a clear crossing, I never seem to think of it. I don't know if acupuncture can help me with that but I wish something could.

That was the one crossing I struggled with today in this delightful puzzle, since I really don't follow golf at all. I've learned a number of terms to expect just by doing the puzzles but I didn't know the name of the event. All I could think of was open. And for vex, I got myself thinking it must be some kind of Latin word. SMH at myself.

Anyhow, I thought it was a really nice puzzle and I enjoyed it a lot! A very pleasant outing! 

I used to go regularly for acupuncture for quite a while and I think this was also a timely reminder for me to resume that practice.  

ROSEBUDS was nice as one of my favorite signs of spring... But what I love the most is how the light stays longer into the evening now.  Ahh!  Hello lightness, my old friend, I've come to talk with you again...  üåûüòâüåû

Anyhow, it's not a yes or no one,  but I'm off to cast an important VOTE in a special election in my fine state.  ü§û

Nice puzzle with a novel theme.

For the record, it took me 1 second longer than yesterday.

We don't have Skittles here so C looked fine there, and in Oskar, so that took a while to figure out. Difficulty was just right for Tuesday I think. But I'm still fuming and that's because of the Sunday puzzle. Commenting there was closed now so I need to vent here. The clueing was just awful and the whole experience was nightmarish. Oh well, starting a new streak now.

Fantastic theme today - won back the chuckle and ‚ÄúAha!‚Äù I missed from yesterday. Laughed out loud at STAB IN THE BACK! 

A fun solve overall - thank you!

Apparently, there's an emu out there without a sense of humor.

My long list of possible nits and its entire thread was taken down.  (As was the poster who apologized to our Canadian constructor for...well, you know what.)

SMH, as they say.

Lovely puzzle. This one was actually easier for me. and more fun,  than yesterday's main puzzle. LOTSA the answers were right in my wheelhouse.

Congratulations to a fellow Torontonian! Let's have more puzzles from Jared Cappel.
Could have sworn it was Tuesday when I woke up.

I enjoyed the theme and felt like I got more than usual of these on the first try!

The northwest corner was the one really challenging area for me -- I was completely unfamiliar with either LPGA or PRO-AM, and I wasn't convinced ASEA was a word. I also went back and forth on "see the point" or "get the point" until I figured out 17A was VOTESYES.

Got there without lookups, though, so I'll call it a win!

STABONTHEBACK/ROPEON forced me to reveal. 
English is my second language so those two sounded perfectly fine to me. Sigh.
Life is hard for us non-golfers.

I've been going through the archives using our wedding anniversary date each year since we got married. With the October 14, 2015 one that I just finished, there was this note on the puzzle: We asked some favorite Times crossword contributors, "What would you like to do in a daily Times crossword that has never been done before?" This week's puzzles, Monday to Saturday, are the result.

Well, it was a really fun one and I recommend it if you are looking for something a little different. I finished somewhere around my normal Wednesday time, so it's not too hard, but it's a bit different (in a good way)!
Printing and framing this! Fantastic!!!
Seeing Acupuncture on a day where I got acupuncture was fun.  The puzzle was a gem with the needle theme.  I loved it!

Anyone else have LOTtA at 57A?  (ASTIN was a no-know for me.)

‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è
One golf clue is hard enough for me, but 3?

This puzzle was so much fun. I do get acupuncture once in a while and it really works. It made for a terrific theme, and it‚Äôs great to see a new constructor with chops. Congrats, Jared Cappel. Hope to see more of you.
Today I learned that the phrase is "id est" ...and not "in est", which  I (and apparently only I) have been saying all my life!

Wow Fourth in Canada in Scrabble, Jared!!! That‚Äôs amazing. üòª I am like last in my small town and I sometimes worry that I love crosswords so much it hurts my Scrabble tournament word memorization but here you are!  I must disabuse myself of that excuse. I‚Äôd love to hear more about how you went from the top of the peak in Scrabble
to NYT Crosswords!

I'm so excited to have the growing season just starting off, I've got some pansies potted up and in the garden providing a splash of color after a long and very cold winter. That said, I don't consider roses a sign of spring. I haven't even pruned my rose back yet to ready it for the new growth to come. Yes, THE rose, the sole survivor of numerous trials. Alas, roses and I just aren't a match. But anyway, the snowdrops are up and blooming and the crocuses, daffodils, tulips, grape hyacinths and standard hyacinths will soon follow, all well before THE rose even has buds. Happy Spring everyone, enjoy the warmth if the weather is providing it where you are. March is fickle, so I know I'll be hauling my pots of pansies inside more than once this month, but it's worth it to finally see some blooms.
@Striker I was really rooting for him, and I was so happy for him!
@DW Same here!  He knocked off a solid champ so now I‚Äôm rooting for Harvey to go on a run of his own.

@Grumpy 

It was AWFUL!
@Steve L  said another way, it was awful. I giggled and thought is a funny.

@Cat Lady Margaret 

I‚Äôve had some miserable experiences with blood draws. So now, whenever I get a phlebotomist or nurse who sticks me without any pain, I make sure to compliment them.

@Eric Hougland 
I do the same thing and usually mention the lack of black & blues on my next visit. It is a most appreciated skill in a "prickly" situation. :D

@Eric Hougland 
I kept a chemo port for eight years after I was told I no longer needed it. After three months of being jabbed for blood draws at least once a day while I was in the hospital post-op  ("Oh, I can do this‚Äîuh, I'll get someone to help‚Äîuh, call phlebotomy and she'll be able to do it"), including a couple of jabs in my foot (don't go there!), always with a "butterfly" needle because my veins collapsed and I was a notoriously "hard stick," it was a godsend to have the port‚Äîit worked every time, first try, and I was afraid to let it go.   My last four recent blood draws post port-removal were easy. I didn't mention "hard stick," as I had been advised to do, and a regular sized needle was used. It held the vein open just fine, perfect flow.

@dutchiris 
Erik, forgot to mention, always, always pre blood tests, drink a lot of water the day before.  A nurse told me to do this and it really improves blood flow.

@Steven M. ,

Thanks, I had 51D wrong as well.

@Francis 

If it requires an initial capital letter, it's a proper noun.

@Steve L 

So then, Islam, Christianity, Buddhism, Protestantism, Catholic...all of those are proper nouns.  

In some cases Mother and Father could be proper nouns.  And Christmas and Labor Day.

Good to know!
@Francis if a title can also be used as a common noun (mother, father), it's not a proper noun. Also, proper adjectives are a thing
@Steven M. Not to be a STICKler, but if the word is used in place of the proper noun ‚Äî e.g. ‚ÄúOh hello, Mother‚Äù ‚Äî it is indeed technically a proper noun, in that case

@Francis Canola refers to "Canadian oil", but it is a marketing term not usually capitalized. BTW, it is IIRC mostly or fully an oil sometimes called rapeseed oil, "rape" or "rabe" being old words for turnip. So you can see why they had to rename this oil.

O, Canada, we love you!.
@Francis "catholic" is also a word in itself that means universal or broad.

@Steven M. 

What Betsy said.

@Graphic 

And "mother" isn't when you're using it as a referent:  She is my mother.

But "Mother" is when you're speaking or referring to a specific person referred to that way:

Coming, Mother.

I had dinner with Father MacKenzie and Mother Teresa.

When I find myself in times of trouble...

@Mike 
You're great at punning!  Stick with it!

@Mike 

Midnight acupuncture is just a shot in the dark.
/
/
/

@Mean Old insert pun here...

ok I'll Qi myself out now

@Renegator 
If I ever get into crossword construction, I‚Äôll have to include [General Secretary of the Communist Party of Czechoslovakia purged in a 1952 show trial] as a clue. (We‚Äôre not related, to my knowledge.)

@Steve L 
Thank you!! I was completely blank on this.  Tripled checked the crosses. No mistakes. Heard the music, but my lack of understanding nagged. Now I have learned something:))

@Jamie 

Why is it OK for you to state your opinion, as you just did, but if others state an opinion you don‚Äôt agree with, that‚Äôs not OK?

@Steve L  sure it‚Äôs fine. But @Jamie just put his opinion out into the ether. The reply is directed at his opinion. I would think that the appropriate response would also be launched into the ether. 

‚Ä¶ which effectively invalidates this comment ‚Ä¶ üòÄ

Jamie, I'm with you, mostly. The previous two puzzles were truly horrible (for me and you, and many others, but not all of us), and today's was quite nice.

However, I am with Steve L, too. When we opine publicly, we have to be prepared for a debate. Ultimately, opining on something is not a zero sum game. I hated yesterday's puzzle passionately, another person loved it - and we were both right. It's not like my hating the puzzle precludes others from loving it.

I also like the sort of logical feedback loop paradox of Iason's comment :D

There is one frequent commenter on here who shows all the restraint and tact of an adolescent boy. With apologies to adolescent boys, some of whom do actually show restraint and tact. Oh well, I guess there‚Äôs one in every online forum (and at least two in this forum). Thank you for your continued vigilance, you add so much to the discussion.
@Grumpier my kingdom for a thumbs down button, even if it does absolutely nothing it would make me feel better

@Steve L sorry Steve. Should have said replies. You're completely welcome to put out your opinion on today's or any other puzzle. You also know as well as I do that "please save" is an idiom and is meant as "I don't want to hear", not that "I won't hear." It just meant I'm sure someone will reply about it because it's the Internet, but I really don't care what their/your opinion is.

@Grumpier 
There is one frequent commenter that makes this forum a much more educational, fun, and lively place to be. There‚Äôs nothing wrong with defending something you love. Learn to roll with the counterpunches and new solvers can grow a lot.

@Striker 

Well said! I second it all.

@Steve L 
Comments for this comment have been disabled.

@Heidi 

Hats waaaaay off!!!!!!  

Two thumbs waaaaay up!!!!!!

Really insightful comment!

@Heidi 

The complatins yesterday were not about proper nouns as such but rather about crossing them, or accumulating many of them in a single area of the puzzle. I was not stumped by ARARAT/UHURA/TARDIS, but there was no way out for me out of the other problematic area, where a podcast producer, city, poet, actor and duck formed a network of arcanity. And on a Monday, of all days!

It really is nice when a name is a gimme (like Atahualpa was for me a few days ago) and it provides you with crosses for the other entries. However, when many names converge on a small area of the grid, and you don't know them, there is no hope for you. Ultimately, I do not think such construction is fair on any day of the week, and on Monday it is simply unacceptable.

I see your point, Heidi, and I agree with it, in principle, however, only with the caveat concerning bunching or crossing proper nouns.

@Heidi 
I used to do some very basic rock climbing. I never made the association until now, but I think it affects the way I approach crosswords.

If you're with a group of people at the base of a cliff, you don't really think of the series of problems you're about to try to solve as being fair or unfair, too easy or too hard. It's just the task before you. Maybe it'll be easy. Maybe it'll be tough. Maybe you'll find out that it's beyond your skill level and you'll have to give up on the attempt.

But you don't blame the cliff.

@Bruce 

The difference between a cliff and a puzzle matters though - a puzzle is a game purpose-made by people for people to enjoy. It is not a work of nature, simply there for millenia. Also, as per NYT custom, the difficulty should increase as the week progresses. To use climbing lingo, Monday is the lowest grade, Saturday the highest. Saturday-ish elements on a Monday (like multiple, and crossing, proper nouns) are just unfair, as a dynamic move, or even a jump, would be on a climbing route given a low grade of difficulty. If I were expected to jump on a training grade climbing route at a gym, I would definitely blame the routesetter and the gym, and I would be right to do so.

Andrzej,

As per Will Shortz' decision -- after several years of editing the puzzles -- Monday is *usually* the lowest grade, Saturday is *usually* the highest. These being puzzles, the grades are sometimes altered to puzzle the solvers. Rebuses don't show up only on Thursdays and Sundays. A Monday may play like a Wednesday. Expect the unexpected. Puzzles are supposed to puzzle us.

@Barry Ancona 

I know, and I like being puzzled, as a rule. But there are fun and unfun kinds of being puzzled, and it would be best if it were slightly more obvious than it has been in recent weeks that the editor cares about a reasonable consistency and quality of the user experience. Bunching five proper and unusual nouns is not against the puzzle rules for Wednesday, or possibly even Monday, maybe, but it is not the best thing that could have happened.

Andrzej, 

In your opinion (which I respect).

In my opinion, it was par for the tricky course.

@Bruce 

I think we should make "cliff-blaming" an official piece of crossword jargon.
And I, as you know, respect your opinion, Barry. I even see your point. I am just not prepared to make it my point ;)

@Heidi Almost all of the "brouhahas" over the puzzle...on any particular day pretty much sound to me like "I cannot do the puzzle.  So it must be too hard".

Its always an abstract piece of data over a word which "virtually no one knows" or "its a Natick...and naticks are mean" or "you made the puzzle too hard for today"

On a regular basis I run into words which I am less than likely to know...I may be too old.  Or I may not be of the social/racial group which would be likely to know that answer.  Or its a topic in life which i just dont give a fig about and would never read or watch something on it...so I know nothing about it.

But there are also words which I do know because of my age...OR because 2500 puzzles ago in a different publication I came across it.  Or maybe I just know more on that topic.

In the end, I always find it more of a philosophy question than some decipherable level of difficulty the puzzle should have.  To me the puzzle is mostly art...Which the editors try to make enjoyable on a daily basis and mostly succeed.

They could very easily quantify the difficulty of a puzzle if they really wanted to....Publish the expected average solving time every day....Publish 7 lists of words acceptable for each day of the week etc.

And that would suck the life out of the puzzle and kill it.  Puzzles are a personal journey...and some legs of that journey are harder than others.
@Grant I had to LOL at your comments too. As a once young lady snowboarder on many a lift line, I've literally heard that line you just gave, so, so, so many times, LOL.

Re the climbing analogies, I think it's kind of a fair analogy. When working on a particular route, its called projecting. It was literally called a project. It's like doing Monday puzzles all the time until I can do it (I'm fairly new to crosswords). Sure the mountain is nature whereas puzzles are human-made, but with both, you learn a bit with each go. You get good at certain parts, find new toeholds or ways to "solve" the problem. Many routes do not call for a dyno, but I had to try that anyway because i could not reach the hold. There's no blame, just what my limited height (or limited exposure to some pronouns) brings. And yet, that entire route, while hard for me, could be "easy" for other climbers.

The point I'm making, as many are, is that there need not be a set-in-stone (no pun intended) formula for Mon, Tues etc. Perhaps there are hard Mondays and easy Tuesdays, without needing the puzzles to switch days. I see it more generally, where Mon-Tues will be, on the whole, easier than Thur-Fri.

I got this Tuesday puzzle with greater ease than yesterday's but that's ok. I figured yesterday had a hard fill, but the theme was "easy" (last part of the entry is doubled). Today, maybe the theme was considered harder but the fill was easier. (That said, I've received acupuncture so that helped, but never heard of Little Lulu).

All in all, they were both fun, and will be easier than what's to come the rest of the week!

@Andrzej 
I hope Jorge‚Äôs journey resolves itself well. Your comment ‚Äúgolf doesn‚Äôt exist in my world‚Äù made me think about the many things that haven‚Äôt existed in my world in my lifetime: war, famine, invasion. Lucky us. I enjoy your little windows into Warsaw here. NICE PUTT crossed with OPED and LOTSA ‚Ä¶ I can‚Äôt imagine tackling a crossword in a foreign language.

@Jennifer 

Whatever happens with Jorge, we will always do what is best for him. I just dread the day it becomes obvious he is suffering no matter what we do... We will deal with it, but it will be so terribly sad. Aaand I actually teared up writing this.

Golf does not exist in my *personal* world, obviously. We have driving ranges and golf courses here. I just find the whole thing terribly uninteresting (which is not the same as boring - I just have no interest in it, at all). Climbing is my sort of sport to do and to watch.

It's a nice day in Warsaw. The sun is out, the sky is blue, and everything is waking from winter slumber. New leaves are budding on trees, bright green blades of grass are beginning to emerge from between last year's wilt, crocuses are blooming, birds are chirping. On days like this I appreciate what a good place to live this is - we have an apartment in a place with lots of green space, on the edge of a nature reserve, and a reasonable walk away from a forest (when Jorge was young, we used to go for 7-13 km runs there), but still only a few minutes away on foot from the metro, shops, restaurants, and anything else you may need to enjoy life daily.

New neighbors have moved in into two apartments in our building this month. They are both nice Ukrainian couples with dogs. They are good people, but their presence here is also a reminder of the horrors they fled.

Life is such a mixed bag, is it not?

@Andrzej 

It's the toughest, and most loving part of being a pet owner.

Seeing them out of the world in the best possible way.

I'm guessing a lot of us are tearing up.  I know I am.

@Andrzej 
I changed my mind a little about golf when I talked with a friend about it. He described it as spending a relaxed day with friends in a park-like setting. Lots of walking and lots of time to talk.

I think the culture that surrounds golf is what's unappealing; the country club exclusivity, the expected (and often required) clothing, the association with business deals, and the competitive nature of the game if it's taken seriously. I understand taking a sport to that level, but if you're the type of person that ends up throwing a club in frustration it doesn't seem worth it.

In my city there's a nine-hole golf course in a city park where showing up in jeans and a T-shirt is perfectly acceptable, and it's in a neighborhood that's always leaned towards the 1960's counterculture, even though it has gentrified. If I were to take up golf, it would be there.

@Andrzej 

Oh Andrzej, I‚Äôm so sorry you‚Äôre suffering.

When our Archie was 14, 
his health suddenly took a nosedive.

A good friend  -who is a veterinarian-
called me to offer support.

I asked her about his suffering,
his pain‚Ä¶all of it.

She told me that my sweet dog
was not, in fact, suffering.
He was feeling unwell.
He trusted us and loved having us near.
The purity of his heart was not 
tainted by worry or fear.

He just didn‚Äôt feel good.

We, however, suffered terribly.

I‚Äôm so sorry for this difficult, heartbreaking time.

How lucky Jorge is to have 
family that cares so very much
and loves him so big.

Funny (haha or peculiar?) how people react differently to the seasons. And it runs so deeply. Winter is heavy on me. Every snowfall makes me wince in almost physical pain. 

Although I also bet that you have a lot longer with the pure snow beauty than I do in the Twin Cities, which is great.  Here, it's almost immediately black and piled up everywhere. Big ugly sooty looking mounds everywhere. I do sometimes appreciate the beauty of a fresh snowfall if I don't have to go out in it. 

I rejoice in the spring because it brings so much hope and joy to me... soon, we will have our full garden balcony of colorful flowers, veggies, and herbs!! Pure joy and freshness abounds! I love to sit out there in the evening with the tomato plants and their glorious aroma brushing against me, hoping no flies land in my martini, while working on the crossword or reading a good book. It's everything! Pure peace! 

Wishing you an easy and gentle spring! <3

@Mean Old Lady From Wikipedia: Blenheim Palace (/Ààbl…õn…™m/ BLEN-im[1]) is a country house in Woodstock, Oxfordshire, England. It is the seat of the Dukes of Marlborough. Originally called Blenheim Castle, it has been known as Blenheim Palace since the 19th century. And although Google calls it Blenheim Palace Castle in England its website basically sticks to "Palace": https://www.blenheimpalace.com/

@Mean Old Lady 

In Europe we generally use the word "castle" to describe a large, fortified building, and not necessarily one ever serving as a residence - many castles were built purely for defense and only featured spartan quarters for the soldiers.

A palace is always a residence, usually grand (but not always - ornate hunting lodges are sometimes called palaces, for example). A palace generally does not feature any fortifications - much like Blenheim.

There may be some confusion, sometimes. A grand residential building within a castle may be called a palace - but the whole thing is still a castle. Also, in the 18th century wealthy Europeans fell in love with the historic style and they started building palaces made to look like castles. Neuschwanstein in Bavaria is a prime example. Those may be called castles, even if they are not, not really.

Finally, it is most common to use the word "castle" for medieval and Renaissance structures, with towers and turrets and the like. Fortified palatial residences of the 16th-18th cent., made up of a palace surrounded by a bastion fortress, are sometimes called castles (like the Polish Krzy≈ºtop√≥r castle in Ujazd), but they may be called palaces just as well.

Yes, I'm into castles ;p
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Krzy%C5%BCtop%C3%B3r Make sure to check out the aerial view. Quite an impressive site and sight, Krzy≈ºtop√≥r is.

@Steve L Interpretation of stats can be subjective similar to the difficulty of a puzzle. I interpret the stats a little different than you do, but not wholly. I completely agree that it shows Monday's was easy for the "pro" solvers and hard for us "novice" solvers. I also feel Tuesday's stats are the norm. Newer solvers tend to beat their average every week. 79% I would expect to be around the norm for a Monday or Tuesday especially since they have a higher number of newer solvers. Monday's was essentially, a 50/50 split. If half of the solvers out there are slower than average then it is indeed a hard puzzle. There are so many questions I have about what's behind the stats. I might have to get a membership to see exactly what I can dig into.

@Steve L I‚Äôm sure you can use the data from that website to make some speculations, but your caveat seems understated. I would expect an absolutely MASSIVE selection effect from such a sample.

FWIW, my speed Monday was significantly faster than my Monday average, bordering (6 seconds over) on a the time threshold that I would consider a particularly fast solve for me. Today‚Äôs solve was almost exactly at my Tuesday average - meaning significantly slower than my current (past year) average. I‚Äôve been solving for about 3 years now.

While it was easier for me personally (based on my own areas of knowledge), Monday seemed like a more difficult puzzle in general (relative to the day of the week), borne out by the comments here - which of course also have a selection effect, but probably not as strong as you would see in the xwstats data.

With wordle-bot and connections-bot, it‚Äôs clear that the NYT collects a ton of data from its games app. While I wouldn‚Äôt expect a NYTxw-bot, I am surprised that the column doesn‚Äôt include a difficulty rating based on app solve times. It seems like it would be a very simple addition. There would still be selection effects, but probably much less pertinent to the general difficulty. It could even show a distribution of solve times so one could see if there was a bimodal distribution or the more expected Gaussian distribution.

@Steve L 
The only thing that makes a crossword easy or difficult for me is the amount of modern slang, US sporting clues, TV channels, brand names, film stars etc are in it, day of the week makes no difference. 

I used to do a cryptic crossword (The Guardian, UK) every day, while commuting. Now that's a workout! I can't do them now. I'd have to re-learn a lot of their conventions. Eg, if there are words like 'mix' 'arrange' 'wild' then that indicates that hidden  inside there is an anagram.

One thing I've noticed, is that the NYT never uses anagrams. They are always in UK crosswords. I wonder why?

@Jane Wheelaghan I think it‚Äôs mainly a difference of style. The cryptic crossword (which I think of as a British style) or the PandA (puns and anagrams) are filled with clues that you can have a pretty good idea if you‚Äôve got the right answer for based on wordplay and the clue alone. Outside of straight trivia clues, the style of the  NYT crossword is such that clues can often have multiple valid answers, for which the crosses are necessary to narrow it down to the one of those possible answers that works with the rest of the puzzle. Moreso the later you get in the week.
